Description.val:
The Operating Forces Industrial Plant Equipment (IPE)budget funds capitalized personal property procurements for the Naval Shipyards and Fleet I-level maintenance activities.  These procurements provide new and efficiency-enabling equipment required to support submarine, CVN, and surface ship maintenance, eliminating reliance on significantly aged and obsolete equipment, including recapitalization of significantly aged Industrial Plant Equipment (IPE), weight handling equipment, and nuclear support equipment infrastructure.  

Improved maintenance capabilities at the activities supported by the Capital Investment Program and Ship Maintenance Investment Program are integral to the Nuclear Enterprise.  Modernizing equipment infrastructure improves maintenance activity productivity and throughput, eliminates workaround and mitigation costs to the Fleet, contributes to decreasing CVN, surface ship, and submarine availability cost and schedule, and improves operational availability.

Funding also support new-mission capital equipment requirements, including VIRGINIA Class introduction at NNSY, concurrent VIRGINIA Class availabilities at PNSY and PHNSY, and LOS ANGELES Class service life extension refueling overhauls at PNSY.

This budget also funds procurement and technical refresh upgrades of all Integrated Condition Assessment System (ICAS) hardware and software aboard Surface Fleet hulls and the Navy Maritime Maintenance Enterprise Solution (NMMES).  NMMES is a strategic investment that has standardized NAVSEA and Fleet ship maintenance functions ashore, controlling and managing all aspects of ship maintenance at the Naval Shipyards, Regional Maintenance Centers (RMCs), and Ship Repair Facilities.

[P40A / KN200:  NAVY MARITIME MAINTENANCE ENTERPRISE SOLUTION SUSTAINMENT]: This funding supports the Navy Maritime Maintenance Enterprise Solution (NMMES) Initiative, a strategic investment that has standardized NAVSEA and Fleet ship maintenance functions ashore, controlling and managing all aspects of ship maintenance at the Naval Shipyards, Regional Maintenance Centers (RMCs), and Ship Repair Facilities.  NMMES manages finance, supply, personnel, time & attendance, repair work processes & planning, scheduling and execution, shop work flow, configuration management, environmental health & safety, quality assurance, up-line management reporting and other functions.  NMMES standardizes and institutionalizes the Navy's ship maintenance business practice processes.  These processes are fully embedded in the NMMES IT systems to gain efficiencies in the maintenance process.  NMMES systems provide the functionality and processes to continually address the maintenance needs of the Fleet, and have a critical role in the efficient brokering, planning, material ordering, financial performance, and execution of shore maintenance.  

This sustainment funding will support procurement of commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) hardware and software in support of NMMES IT systems, including the Electronic Technical Work Document (ETWD) initiative.

[P40A / KN201:  NAVY MARITIME MAINTENANCE ENTERPRISE SOLUTION TECHNICAL REFRESH (NMMES-TR)]: The NMMES-TR plan for acquisition that has been endorsed by the Executive Steering Committee and recently approved at a Gate 2 Review by the R3B is to procure initial COTS licenses in FY18 that could address the functional requirements for work brokering, MRO requirements management and scheduling.  

These licenses will be used to either prototype a potential solution or procure software licenses to address the critical need to replace the Validation Screening And Brokering (VSB), Regional Maintenance Automated Information System (RMAIS), and Project Sequencing and Scheduling systems (PSS) that are either unsupported or not fulfilling the required functional requirement.

[P40A / KN300:  SHIPYARD CAPITAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM (CIP)]: Provides funding for the Shipyard Capital Investment Program (CIP) in support of the four mission funded Naval Shipyards and attached and Intermediate Maintenance Facilities (IMF).  Funds will be used for the procurement and execution of Class 3 & 4 plant and personal property projects to maintain, modernize and improve the infrastructure and industrial base at the mission funded Naval Shipyard/IMF activities.  Funding will allow for the acquisition of equipment and OP,N related Automated Data Processing (ADP) Hardware/Software necessary to perform the mission of repairing, conversion, and modernization of fleet ships and submarines in the most economical, efficient, environmentally sound and safe manner possible.  Continued reliance on an aged capital equipment infrastructure increases submarine and aircraft carrier depot maintenance availability costs and places schedules at risk.

Shipyard capital equipment investments are in accordance with the February 2018 Shipyard Infrastructure Optimization Plan Report to Congress as well as supporting new mission requirements, such as LOS ANGELES Class service life extension refueling availabilities at Portsmouth Naval Shipyard.  The full FY 2020 request is urgently required to modernize the Naval Shipyard equipment infrastructure to improve depot maintenance throughput in support of their mission.  

NOTE that the budget year equipment requirements provided in this exhibit are based on current Shipyard priorities to best improve submarine and aircraft carrier availability execution within currently projected budget.  Projected costs are best government estimates based on market research and are subject to change.  Changes to program funding, realized costs, and/or realization of emergent Shipyard equipment requirements after budget submittal could impact the requirements identified in this exhibit.

[P40A / SHIPYARD CAPITAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM (CIP)]: Improved maintenance capabilities at the Naval Shipyards are integral to the Nuclear Enterprise.  Procurement of new and efficiency-enabling capital equipment to repair CVNs and submarines in accordance with the February 2018 Shipyard Infrastructure Optimization Plan Report to Congress contributes to decreasing availability costs and schedules, ultimately returning mission days to the Fleet and moving the needle on Shipyard throughput.

The KN300 Capital Investment Program funding includes the $150M/year capital equipment modernization requirement provided in the February 2018 Shipyard Infrastructure Optimization Report to Congress, in addition to new mission investments required to execute LOS ANGELES Class refueling service life extensions at PNSY, which is critical to supporting the 355 ship fleet.

The Operating Forces IPE Budget for the Shipyard Capital Investment Program has been restructured to identify and break out individual component costs for acquisitions over $10M that were consolidated within Item Numbers in previous budget submits.

[P40A / Portal Crane]: Procures a new high hook speed portal crane for PSNS&IMF, Bremerton (Shipyard site).  This procurement directly supports an increase in workload for the Shipyard that requires additional portal cranes to meet project demands. This crane is designed to fill a critical capability gap for pier and dry dock support. Continued reliance on existing crane population will continue exposure to increasing costs to customer due to lack of support causing delays to the projects, increasing costs to maintain, support, and operate rental/lease cranes, and increasing costs and lower efficiency using higher capacity portal cranes to lift lighter, repetitive loads.

[P40A / CNC Shaft Lathe]: Procures two Computer Numerically Controlled (CNC) shaft lathes required by NNSY and PSNSY to support depot availability critical path submarine and CVN shaft maintenance as well as the shaft rotatable pool.

[P40A / 175 TON HEAVY LIFT PORTAL CRANE]: The FY19 175 ton heavy lift portal crane is required to execute LOS ANGELES Class refueling evolutions at PNSY.  Refueling lifts cannot be executed using existing 60 ton portal crane infrastructure.

FY20 and later 175 ton heavy lift portal crane acquisitions recapitalize existing shipyard assets that are in poor material condition, beyond maximum expected service life, and are experiencing repair parts obsolescence issues.  These heavy lift portal cranes are required for critical path submarine and CVN nuclear defueling and refueling weight handling evolutions that can't be executed using the remaining lower capacity portal crane Fleet as well as supporting all depot maintenance lifting and handling requirements.

[P40A / REFUELING STORAGE ENCLOSURE]: PNSY Refueling Storage Enclosure that is required to execute LOS ANGELES Class refueling evolutions at PNSY IAW current schedule.

[P40A / REFUELING COMPLEX]: Modify PNSY Dry Dock 1 defueling complex to add submarine refueling capabilities.  This acquisition is required to execute LOS ANGELES Class refueling evolutions at PNSY IAW current schedule.

[P40A / NFPC SU-12 Propeller Profiler Replacement]: Replaces existing Navy Foundry and Propeller Center (NFPC) propeller profiler with a new CNC milling machine.  This acquisition is required to support VIRGINIA Class and COLUMBIA Class propulsor manufacture and repair.

[P40A / VIRGINIA Class Propulsor Hanlding System]: Provides stacking stands, platforms, Heavy Lift Transporters (HLTs) and the necessary Lifting and Handling system to remove, stow, and reinstall the VIRGINIA Class Propulsor and shaft assembly during depot availabilities.  Without this procurement, NNSY will be unable to support assigned VIRGINIA Class depot maintenance. This is the only approved system design for executing these precise and demanding Propulsor and shaft maintenance actions.

[P40A / KNCA1: SHIPYARD CAPITAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM (CIP) CONGRESSIONAL ADD]: Provides funding for the Shipyard Capital Investment Program (CIP) in support of the four mission funded Naval Shipyards and attached and Intermediate Maintenance Facilities (IMF).  KNCA1 captures FY19 congressional add funding provided to accelerate shipyard infrastructure optimization, breaking out individual component costs for acquisitions over $10M.  

Funds will be used for the procurement and execution of Class 3 & 4 plant and personal property projects to maintain, modernize and improve the infrastructure and industrial base at the mission funded Naval Shipyard/IMF activities.  Funding will allow for the acquisition of equipment and OPN related Automated Data Processing (ADP) Hardware/Software necessary to perform the mission of repairing, conversion, and modernization of fleet ships and submarines in the most economical, efficient, environmentally sound and safe manner possible.  Continued reliance on an aged capital equipment infrastructure increases submarine and aircraft carrier depot maintenance availability costs and places schedules at risk.

[P40A / SHIPYARD CAPITAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM (CIP) CONGRESSIONAL ADD]: Improved maintenance capabilities at the Naval Shipyards are integral to the Nuclear Enterprise.  Procurement of new and efficiency-enabling capital equipment to repair CVNs and submarines in accordance with the February 2018 Shipyard Infrastructure Optimization Plan Report to Congress contributes to decreasing availability costs and schedules, ultimately returning mission days to the Fleet and moving the needle on Shipyard throughput.  KNCA1 captures FY19 congressional add funding provided to accelerate shipyard infrastructure optimization.  No individual FY19 CA acquisitions exceed $10M for inclusion as discrete cost elements.

[P40A / KN400:  SHIP MAINTENANCE INVESTMENT PROGRAM]: Provides funding to support capital investments for the Regional Maintenance Centers (RMCs), including forward deployed RMCs, Trident Refit Facility (TRF) Kings Bay (KB), Naval Submarine Support Facility New London (NSSF NL), and Navy Base Guam.  Funds will be used for the procurement and execution of personal property projects (including Industrial Plant Equipment (IPE), IT HW/SW, lifting and handling equipment, MILCON collateral equipment, etc.) of a capital nature (greater then $250K) to maintain and  modernize the ship maintenance industrial base, with a focus on reducing total ownership costs.  These personal property projects are required for the RMCs, NSSF NL, Navy Base Guam, and TRF KB to perform their mission of repairing, conversion, and modernization of fleet ships and submarines.

[P40A / KN504:  SRF-JRMC Capital Investment Program]: Procures capital investment items required to maintain and modernize the Fleet's ship maintenance industrial base at Ship Repair Facility - Japan Regional Maintenance Center (SRF-JRMC).  Funds will be used for the procurement and execution of personal property projects (including Industrial Plant Equipment (IPE), IT HW/SW, lifting and handling equipment, material handling equipment, MILCON collateral equipment, etc.) of a capital nature (greater then $250K) to maintain and  modernize the ship maintenance industrial base, with a focus on reducing total ownership costs.  These personal property projects are required by SRF-JRMC to support its mission of repairing, conversion, and modernization of fleet surface ships.

[P40A / KN507:  SRF-JRMC Capital Investment Program]: Procures capital investment items required to maintain and modernize the Fleet's ship maintenance industrial base at Ship Repair Facility - Japan Regional Maintenance Center (SRF-JRMC).  Funds will be used for the procurement and execution of personal property projects (including Industrial Plant Equipment (IPE), IT HW/SW, lifting and handling equipment, material handling equipment, MILCON collateral equipment, etc.) of a capital nature (greater then $250K) to maintain and  modernize the ship maintenance industrial base, with a focus on reducing total ownership costs.  These personal property projects are required by SRF-JRMC to support its mission of repairing, conversion, and modernization of fleet surface ships.

[P40A / Portal Cranes]: Replacement of old equipment.  Crane support is required to support 7th Fleet ship maintenance and repair.  Heavy lift capacity of the portal crane at the dry docks provides capabilities for shaft repair/replacement, rudder/post, propeller, sonar dome, highly political/sensitive lifts involving RAM from USS REAGAN; and setting of dry docks (requires lowering of forklifts, blocks, and mobile cranes into dock); and in extreme cases MRG replacement as accomplished on McCAMPBELL.  Two cranes  are required at a dock to allow flexibility to (i) keep up with high workloads, (ii) perform heavier lifts (e.g. shaft) which is beyond the capacity of a single crane, and (iii) allow maintenance cycles (50-60 days) on the cranes without impacting ship maintenance.

[P40A / KN508: OPERATION FREEDOM SENTINEL VEHICLE PROCUREMENT]: OPERATION FREEDOM SENTINEL - IN THEATER - VEHICLE PROCUREMENT

[P40A / VEHICLE PROCUREMENT]: OPERATION FREEDOM SENTINEL VEHICLE PROCUREMENT

[P40A / KN800:  INTEGRATED CONDITION ASSESSMENT SYSTEM (ICAS) NEW INSTALL]: Procures all new installations of the Integrated Condition Assessment System (ICAS) hardware and software aboard Surface Fleet hulls.  New Installation include: ICAS workstation hardware (including Palm Pilot Portable Data Terminal (PDTs)), latest version of ICAS system software, Configuration Data Set (CDS) (including the implementation of developed enhancements), firewall (if applicable), remote monitoring utility (RMU), ILS and ship's force training.  Manage contractor efforts, prepare installation plans, perform ship checks, procure material, oversee shipboard installation and Quality Assurance (QA), develop/implement CDS, install/test all software and CDSs, provide ship's force training.

[P40A / KN900:  INTEGRATED CONDITION ASSESSMENT SYSTEM (ICAS) TECH REFRESH]: Procures all technical refresh upgrades of the Integrated Condition Assessment System (ICAS) hardware and software aboard Surface Fleet hulls. Upgrades will include: ICAS workstation hardware (including Palm Pilot Portable Data Terminal (PDTs)), latest version of ICAS system software, Configuration Data Set (CDS) groom (including the implementation of developed enhancements), firewall (if applicable), remote monitoring utility (RMU), and ship's force refresher training. Manage contractor efforts, prepare installation plans, perform ship checks, procure material, oversee shipboard installation and Quality Assurance (QA), develop/implement CDS updates, install/test all software and CDSs, provide ship's force training.

Justification.val:
The Operating Forces Industrial Plant Equipment (IPE) for the Shipyard Capital Investment Program and NMMES Sustainment have been restructured to identify and break out individual component costs for acquisitions over $10M that were consolidated within Item Numbers in previous budget submits.

FY18 and later KN300 Capital Investment Program funding includes the $150M/year capital equipment modernization requirement provided in the February 2018 Shipyard Infrastructure Optimization Report to Congress, in addition to new mission investments such as equipment infrastructure required to execute LOS ANGELES Class refueling service life extensions at PNSY, which is critical to supporting the 355 ship fleet.

FY19 Congressional Add funding provided to accelerate shipyard infrastructure optimization.  Additionally, FY19 is the last year OPN BLI 1445 funding is provided for Navy Maintenance Enterprise Solution Technical Refresh (NMMES-TR) program.  FY19 and FY20 include additional funding for capital equipment investments required for new mission refueling evolutions at Portsmouth Naval Shipyard (PNSY) ($49.4M in FY19 and $30M in FY20).

Name.val: 1) KN200:  NAVY MARITIME MAINTENANCE ENTERPRISE SOLUTION SUSTAINMENT

Name.@footnote: FY19 to FY20 increase for KN200 was due to the increased FY20 programming of funds to identified requirements that support hardware and software for ship maintenance systems, including; product data management hardware/software, enterprise data analytics software, cybersecurity vulnerability software, and increased hardware capacity at Navy data centers.
Name.val: 1.1) NAVY MARITIME MAINTENANCE ENTERPRISE SOLUTION SUSTAINMENT
2) KN201:  NAVY MARITIME MAINTENANCE ENTERPRISE SOLUTION TECHNICAL REFRESH (NMMES-TR)
2.1) NAVY MARITIME MAINTENANCE ENTERPRISE SOLUTION TECHNICAL REFRESH

Name.@footnote: Portal crane acquisition budgets are based on the negotiated costs of these 25 ton portal cranes in the IDIQ acquisition contract.  The first (FY18) PSNS&IMF Bremerton site crane includes site-specific fitup, CDRL deliverables, acceptance testing, and engineering efforts and associated costs that only apply to the first Bremerton site acquisition and are not repeated for the second (FY19) and later Bremerton site acquisitions.
FY20 funding for this requirement is needed to ensure equipment is available at NNSY to execute the FY22 USS JOHN WARNER depot maintenance availability.

Name.val: 4) KNCA1: SHIPYARD CAPITAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM (CIP) CONGRESSIONAL ADD
4.1) SHIPYARD CAPITAL INVESTMENT PROGRAM (CIP) CONGRESSIONAL ADD

Name.@footnote: Funding ends in FY19 (CFFC).  SRF-JRMC Capital Investment Program transitioned from Commander Pacific Fleet to Naval Sea Systems Command PPBE oversight beginning with PB20.  Zero-sum tech adjust to change BSO from 70 to 24. Consolidates OPN LI 1445 under BSO 24 for increased management efficiencies in programming and execution for shipyard equipment infrastructure across all government shipyards. The Fleet and NAVSEA will prioritize equipment investments across the enterprise using a standardized process administered by NAVSEA.

Funding starts in FY20 (NAVSEA).  SRF-JRMC Capital Investment Program transitioned from Commander Pacific Fleet to Naval Sea Systems Command PPBE oversight beginning with PB20.  Zero-sum tech adjust to change BSO from 70 to 24. Consolidates OPN LI 1445 under BSO 24 for increased management efficiencies in programming and execution for shipyard equipment infrastructure across all government shipyards. The Fleet and NAVSEA will prioritize equipment investments across the enterprise using a standardized process administered by NAVSEA.
